elements.content: The partially fluorinated metal–organic frameworks (F-MOFs) have been constructed from 3-fluoro-4-pyridinecarboxylic acid and trans-3-fluoro-4-pyridineacrylic acid linkers using Mn2+, Co2+, and Cd2+ metals via the solvothermal method, which show isostructural isomerism with their nonfluorinated counterparts synthesized using 4-pyridinecarboxylic acid and trans-4-pyridineacrylic acid, respectively. The simultaneous effect of partial fluorination and isoreticulation on structure and H2 adsorption has been studied systematically in isostructural nonfluorinated and partially fluorinated MOFs, which shows that the increment in the hydrogen uptake properties in F-MOFs is not a universal phenomenon but is rather system-specific and changes from one system to another.
elements.clean_text: The partially fluorinated metal-organic frameworks (F-MOFs) have been constructed from 3-fluoro-4-pyridinecarboxylic acid and trans-3-fluoro-4-pyridineacrylic acid linkers using Mn2+, Co2+, and Cd2+ metals via the solvothermal method, which show isostructural isomerism with their nonfluorinated counterparts synthesized using 4-pyridinecarboxylic acid and trans-4-pyridineacrylic acid, respectively. The simultaneous effect of partial fluorination and isoreticulation on structure and H2 adsorption has been studied systematically in isostructural nonfluorinated and partially fluorinated MOFs, which shows that the increment in the hydrogen uptake properties in F-MOFs is not a universal phenomenon but is rather system-specific and changes from one system to another.

elements.content: The simultaneous effect of isoreticulation and fluorine functionalization on the structures and H2 adsorption properties have been demonstrated using pairs of isostructural and isoreticular metal−organic frameworks synthesized using pyridinecarboxylate linkers with Mn2+, Co2+, and Co2+ metal centers.
elements.clean_text: The simultaneous effect of isoreticulation and fluorine functionalization on the structures and H2 adsorption properties have been demonstrated using pairs of isostructural and isoreticular metal-organic frameworks synthesized using pyridinecarboxylate linkers with Mn2+, Co2+, and Co2+ metal centers.

elements.content: In order to replace traditional fossil fuels, increased usage of renewable energy resources, such as fuel cells, supercapacitors, solar cells, etc., has been witnessed. Because of the high energy density and emission free energy production, fuel cells are gaining considerable importance. However, hydrogen storage in large content is infeasible because of hydrogen’s low molecular weight and very less critical temperature, which are the main obstacles for the commercialization of fuel cells. The technologies used for hydrogen storage, such as high-pressure compression and liquification, are regarded as impractical not only because of low hydrogen storage capacity but also because of high cost. In these regard, to improve the hydrogen storage capacity, alternatives such as chemical and physical hydrogen storage have been attempted. Because of the reversibility for a large number of cycles and high gravimetric and volumetric storage capacities, physisorptive hydrogen storage is preferred. Although porous materials, such as carbon, graphene, carbon nanotubes, zeolites, silica, etc., have been used for hydrogen storage, the low porosity with broad pore-size distribution and limited hydrogen uptake restrict their practical applications. However, because of their highly porous but tunable architecture, high hydrogen storage capacity, and good recyclability, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), consisting of metal clusters coordinated to organic linkers, are considered to be the best materials for hydrogen storage.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In order to replace traditional fossil fuels, increased usage of renewable energy resources, such as fuel cells, supercapacitors, solar cells, etc., has been witnessed. Because of the high energy density and emission free energy production, fuel cells are gaining considerable importance. However, hydrogen storage in large content is infeasible because of hydrogen's low molecular weight and very less critical temperature, which are the main obstacles for the commercialization of fuel cells. The technologies used for hydrogen storage, such as high-pressure compression and liquification, are regarded as impractical not only because of low hydrogen storage capacity but also because of high cost. In these regard, to improve the hydrogen storage capacity, alternatives such as chemical and physical hydrogen storage have been attempted. Because of the reversibility for a large number of cycles and high gravimetric and volumetric storage capacities, physisorptive hydrogen storage is preferred. Although porous materials, such as carbon, graphene, carbon nanotubes, zeolites, silica, etc., have been used for hydrogen storage, the low porosity with broad pore-size distribution and limited hydrogen uptake restrict their practical applications. However, because of their highly porous but tunable architecture, high hydrogen storage capacity, and good recyclability, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), consisting of metal clusters coordinated to organic linkers, are considered to be the best materials for hydrogen storage.

elements.content: Although porous MOFs synthesized using a variety of organic linkers and metal centers have been used for hydrogen storage, their storage capacities are still lagging behind the Department of Energy (DOE) targets. In order to further improve the hydrogen storage capacities, strategies such as functionalization, interpenetration, doping of metal ions and transition-metal nanoparticles, and synthesis of high-porosity MOFs have been endeavored. However, highly porous MOFs with extremely light weights and low densities of less than 0.5–0.8 g cm–3 result in low volumetric H2 uptake despite their high gravimetric uptake. Under these circumstances, the synthesis of MOFs having reasonable surface areas and moderate densities with high adsorbate–adsorbent interactions may enable higher gravimetric as well as volumetric uptake. For this purpose, the synthesis of MOFs functionalized with different functional groups, such as −NH2, −COOH, −NO2, −F, −CF3, etc., have been attempted for higher hydrogen storage capacities. These functionalized MOFs have shown improved hydrogen–framework interaction, leading to high hydrogen storage in MOFs through improved heats of adsorption.
elements.clean_text: Although porous MOFs synthesized using a variety of organic linkers and metal centers have been used for hydrogen storage, their storage capacities are still lagging behind the Department of Energy (DOE) targets. In order to further improve the hydrogen storage capacities, strategies such as functionalization, interpenetration, doping of metal ions and transition-metal nanoparticles, and synthesis of high-porosity MOFs have been endeavored. However, highly porous MOFs with extremely light weights and low densities of less than 0.5-0.8 g cm-3 result in low volumetric H2 uptake despite their high gravimetric uptake. Under these circumstances, the synthesis of MOFs having reasonable surface areas and moderate densities with high adsorbate-adsorbent interactions may enable higher gravimetric as well as volumetric uptake. For this purpose, the synthesis of MOFs functionalized with different functional groups, such as -NH2, -COOH, -NO2, -F, -CF3, etc., have been attempted for higher hydrogen storage capacities. These functionalized MOFs have shown improved hydrogen-framework interaction, leading to high hydrogen storage in MOFs through improved heats of adsorption.

elements.content: Functionalized MOFs with highly electronegative functional groups or atoms like −CF3 and −F have been found to be effective for improving the heats of adsorption as well as hydrogen storage capacities. The improved adsorbate–adsorbent interactions among hydrogen and most electronegative −F atoms show better hydrogen adsorption capacities in partially or fully fluorinated MOFs (F-MOFs). In these regard, we and others have shown that fluorine-functionalized MOFs have good promise for hydrogen storage, where hydrogen storage capacities of up to 2 wt % (77 K, 1 bar) have been achieved. However, it has been observed that the higher densities of F-MOFs and increased van der Waals radii of −F atoms compared to those of hydrogen further restrict the adsorption capacities. Assuming the importance of F-MOFs for high hydrogen storage, in order to overcome the issues related to decreased porosities and higher densities, the synthesis of F-MOFs with moderate porosities is desired.
elements.clean_text: Functionalized MOFs with highly electronegative functional groups or atoms like -CF3 and -F have been found to be effective for improving the heats of adsorption as well as hydrogen storage capacities. The improved adsorbate-adsorbent interactions among hydrogen and most electronegative -F atoms show better hydrogen adsorption capacities in partially or fully fluorinated MOFs (F-MOFs). In these regard, we and others have shown that fluorine-functionalized MOFs have good promise for hydrogen storage, where hydrogen storage capacities of up to 2 wt % (77 K, 1 bar) have been achieved. However, it has been observed that the higher densities of F-MOFs and increased van der Waals radii of -F atoms compared to those of hydrogen further restrict the adsorption capacities. Assuming the importance of F-MOFs for high hydrogen storage, in order to overcome the issues related to decreased porosities and higher densities, the synthesis of F-MOFs with moderate porosities is desired.

elements.content: Herein, to improve the hydrogen storage capacities of MOFs, we synthesized F-MOFs and their nonfluorinated counterparts by applying the functionalization and isoreticulation phenomena simultaneously ( and S1). In particular, utilization of 4-pyridinecarboxylic acid (isonicotinic acid, INA) and its fluorine-functionalized organic linker 3-fluoro-4-pyridinecarboxylic acid (3-fluoroisonicotinic acid, FINA) have been attempted for the synthesis of MOFs using Mn2+, Co2+, and Cd2+ metals. Further, the respective isoreticular counterparts of INA- and FINA-based MOFs have been synthesized using trans-4-pyridineacrylic acid (PAA) and trans-3-fluoro-4-pyridineacrylic acid (FPAA) linkers with the same metal ions ( and S1). The characterization of as-synthesized MOFs have been performed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and Fourier transform infrared (FTIR). The porosity details and adsorption behavior of these MOFs have been determined using nitrogen (N2) and hydrogen (H2) adsorption isotherms.
elements.clean_text: Herein, to improve the hydrogen storage capacities of MOFs, we synthesized F-MOFs and their nonfluorinated counterparts by applying the functionalization and isoreticulation phenomena simultaneously ( and S1). In particular, utilization of 4-pyridinecarboxylic acid (isonicotinic acid, INA) and its fluorine-functionalized organic linker 3-fluoro-4-pyridinecarboxylic acid (3-fluoroisonicotinic acid, FINA) have been attempted for the synthesis of MOFs using Mn2+, Co2+, and Cd2+ metals. Further, the respective isoreticular counterparts of INA- and FINA-based MOFs have been synthesized using trans-4-pyridineacrylic acid (PAA) and trans-3-fluoro-4-pyridineacrylic acid (FPAA) linkers with the same metal ions ( and S1). The characterization of as-synthesized MOFs have been performed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and Fourier transform infrared (FTIR). The porosity details and adsorption behavior of these MOFs have been determined using nitrogen (N2) and hydrogen (H2) adsorption isotherms.

elements.content: Synthesis and crystal structures of MOFs. Scheme of the synthesis of MOFs using INA, FINA, PAA, and FPAA linkers with Mn2+, Co2+, and Cd2+ metal centers, solvothermally. The SBUs of the nonfluorinated MOFs and their partially fluorinated isomers are represented. H atoms are omitted for clarity. Color code: Mn, green; Co, brown; Cd, violet; C, silver; F, light green; O, red; N, light blue.
elements.clean_text: 1  Synthesis and crystal structures of MOFs. Scheme of the synthesis of MOFs using INA, FINA, PAA, and FPAA linkers with Mn2+, Co2+, and Cd2+ metal centers, solvothermally. The SBUs of the nonfluorinated MOFs and their partially fluorinated isomers are represented. H atoms are omitted for clarity. Color code: Mn, green; Co, brown; Cd, violet; C, silver; F, light green; O, red; N, light blue.

elements.content: Isonicotinic acid (INA) and 3-fluoroisonicotinic acid (FINA) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used as received. The syntheses of trans-4-pyridineacrylic acid (PAA) and trans-3-fluoro-4-pyridineacrylic acid (FPAA) were carried out following the literature procedure using 4-pyridinecarbaldehyde and 3-fluoro-4-pyridinecarbaldehyde purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Mn­(NO3)2·xH2O, Co­(NO3)2·6H2O, and Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used as received. All experimental operations were performed in air, and all of the stock solutions were prepared in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

Isonicotinic acid (INA) and 3-fluoroisonicotinic acid (FINA) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used as received. The syntheses of trans-4-pyridineacrylic acid (PAA) and trans-3-fluoro-4-pyridineacrylic acid (FPAA) were carried out following the literature procedure using 4-pyridinecarbaldehyde and 3-fluoro-4-pyridinecarbaldehyde purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Mn(NO3)2⋅xH2O, Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O, and Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used as received. All experimental operations were performed in air, and all of the stock solutions were prepared in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF).

elements.content: The synthesis of MOFs reported herein was performed solvothermally, in an organic solvent. DMF solutions of the respective metal salt (0.5 mL, 0.20 M) and pyridinecarboxylate linker (1.5 mL, 0.20 M) were mixed in a 5 mL glass vial, and 0.5 mL of EtOH was added to the same mixture. The vial was capped and heated to 85 °C for 72 h. The mother liquor was decanted, and MOF crystals were filtered off, washed with DMF, and dried in air (10 min). Syntheses of INA-based Mn-INA-1 and Cd-INA-1, FINA-based Mn-FINA-1 and Cd-FINA-1, PAA-based Mn-PAA-1, Co-PAA-1, and Cd-PAA-1, and FPAA-based Mn-FPAA-1, Co-FPAA-1, and Cd-FPAA-1 have been performed using the respective metal salts, while keeping other conditions unchanged (section S1 in the Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of MOFs

The synthesis of MOFs reported herein was performed solvothermally, in an organic solvent. DMF solutions of the respective metal salt (0.5 mL, 0.20 M) and pyridinecarboxylate linker (1.5 mL, 0.20 M) were mixed in a 5 mL glass vial, and 0.5 mL of EtOH was added to the same mixture. The vial was capped and heated to 85 °C for 72 h. The mother liquor was decanted, and MOF crystals were filtered off, washed with DMF, and dried in air (10 min). Syntheses of INA-based Mn-INA-1 and Cd-INA-1, FINA-based Mn-FINA-1 and Cd-FINA-1, PAA-based Mn-PAA-1, Co-PAA-1, and Cd-PAA-1, and FPAA-based Mn-FPAA-1, Co-FPAA-1, and Cd-FPAA-1 have been performed using the respective metal salts, while keeping other conditions unchanged (section S1 in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: Low-pressure volumetric gas adsorption measurements involved in this work were performed at 77 K and maintained by a liquid-nitrogen bath on a Quantachrome Quadrasorb automatic volumetric instrument. In all adsorption measurements, ultrahigh-purity H2 was obtained by using calcium aluminosilicate adsorbents to remove trace amounts of water (H2O) and other impurities before introduction into the system. Microcrystals of each MOF were soaked in a 1:1 dry dichloromethane and methanol mixture for 12 h. A fresh 1:1 dry dichloromethane and methanol mixture was subsequently added, and the crystals were allowed to stay for an additional 48 h to remove coordinated and free solvates (DMF and EtOH) present in the framework. The sample was dried under a dynamic vacuum at room temperature for 6 h. The coordinated solvents DMF, EtOH, and H2O molecules on the SBUs remain in the framework at this stage. To remove coordinated solvents, samples were heated at 60 °C for 12 h and 100 °C for 12 h under a dynamic vacuum.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Adsorption Measurements

Low-pressure volumetric gas adsorption measurements involved in this work were performed at 77 K and maintained by a liquid-nitrogen bath on a Quantachrome Quadrasorb automatic volumetric instrument. In all adsorption measurements, ultrahigh-purity H2 was obtained by using calcium aluminosilicate adsorbents to remove trace amounts of water (H2O) and other impurities before introduction into the system. Microcrystals of each MOF were soaked in a 1:1 dry dichloromethane and methanol mixture for 12 h. A fresh 1:1 dry dichloromethane and methanol mixture was subsequently added, and the crystals were allowed to stay for an additional 48 h to remove coordinated and free solvates (DMF and EtOH) present in the framework. The sample was dried under a dynamic vacuum at room temperature for 6 h. The coordinated solvents DMF, EtOH, and H2O molecules on the SBUs remain in the framework at this stage. To remove coordinated solvents, samples were heated at 60 °C for 12 h and 100 °C for 12 h under a dynamic vacuum.

elements.content: The crystal structures of Mn-, Co-, and Cd-based MOFs comprised of INA and FINA linkers are determined using single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses ( and ). These crystal structures consist of doubly bridged infinite manganese­(2+), cobalt­(2+), and cadmium­(2+) carboxylate chains (Figures S2–S5 and Tables S1, S2, S7, and S8). In these MOFs, the pyridine functionalities of the INA and FINA ligands point outward from the chains. The resulting strands cross-link by metal–N coordination to generate the three-dimenisonal (3D) frameworks. In Mn-INA-1, Mn-FINA-1, and Cd-FINA-1, each octahedral Mn2+/Cd2+ metal center connects to the four INA/FINA ligands through one of their μ2-carboxyl O atoms and the two INA ligands through their pyridyl N atoms (Figure S6). Each SBU connects to the next through INA/FINA ligands to generate the 3D structure. However, in the case of Cd-INA-1, each pentagonal-bipyramidal Cd2+ center connects to two μ1-carboxyl O atoms, two INA ligands through their pyridyl N atoms, and one H2O molecule ( and S4). Each SBU connects to the next through INA ligands to generate the 3D-interpenetrated structure, with diamondoid (dia) topology (Figure S4). Except Cd-INA-1, all other MOF structures are noninterpenetrated with square-shaped pores, where uncoordinated H2O or DMF molecules are residing at the center. The structure of Mn-INA-1 is isostructural to Mn-FINA-1, similar to those of Co-INA-2 and Co-FINA-2, which are reported elsewhere. A comparison between the cell dimensions for Mn-INA-1 (a = 9.954, b = 13.136, and c = 11.009) and Mn-FINA-1 (a = 10.069, b = 12.946, and c = 11.319) reveals that these structures are very similar to each other, despite changes in the linker functionalities in INA and FINA. However, a comparison between the cell dimensions for Mn-FINA-1 and Cd-FINA-1 (a = 4.770, b = 13.204, and c = 10.669) reveals that, although the b and c axes are similar in dimensions, the a axis of the Mn-FINA-1 unit cell is approximately double that of Cd-FINA-1 (doubling of the a axis is expected from randomization/disorder of the pyridine ring orientations in the Cd-FINA-1 structure), which was previously observed in the case of Co-INA-2 and Co-FINA-2 (Tables S1, S2, S7, and S8). Despite having similar unit cells and crystal structures, Mn-INA-1 has bigger pore dimensions (2.8 × 6.5 Å2) compared to Mn-FINA-1 (2.1 × 3.4 Å2) because the F atoms point into the pores (). Similarly, the interpenetrated structure of Cd-INA-1 (2.2 × 6.6 Å2) has higher pore dimensions than those of Cd-FINA-1 (2.6 × 3.1 Å2).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structures

The crystal structures of Mn-, Co-, and Cd-based MOFs comprised of INA and FINA linkers are determined using single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses ( and ). These crystal structures consist of doubly bridged infinite manganese(2+), cobalt(2+), and cadmium(2+) carboxylate chains (Figures S2-S5 and Tables S1, S2, S7, and S8). In these MOFs, the pyridine functionalities of the INA and FINA ligands point outward from the chains. The resulting strands cross-link by metal-N coordination to generate the three-dimenisonal (3D) frameworks. In Mn-INA-1, Mn-FINA-1, and Cd-FINA-1, each octahedral Mn2+/Cd2+ metal center connects to the four INA/FINA ligands through one of their μ2-carboxyl O atoms and the two INA ligands through their pyridyl N atoms (Figure S6). Each SBU connects to the next through INA/FINA ligands to generate the 3D structure. However, in the case of Cd-INA-1, each pentagonal-bipyramidal Cd2+ center connects to two μ1-carboxyl O atoms, two INA ligands through their pyridyl N atoms, and one H2O molecule ( and S4). Each SBU connects to the next through INA ligands to generate the 3D-interpenetrated structure, with diamondoid (dia) topology (Figure S4). Except Cd-INA-1, all other MOF structures are noninterpenetrated with square-shaped pores, where uncoordinated H2O or DMF molecules are residing at the center. The structure of Mn-INA-1 is isostructural to Mn-FINA-1, similar to those of Co-INA-2 and Co-FINA-2, which are reported elsewhere. A comparison between the cell dimensions for Mn-INA-1 (a = 9.954, b = 13.136, and c = 11.009) and Mn-FINA-1 (a = 10.069, b = 12.946, and c = 11.319) reveals that these structures are very similar to each other, despite changes in the linker functionalities in INA and FINA. However, a comparison between the cell dimensions for Mn-FINA-1 and Cd-FINA-1 (a = 4.770, b = 13.204, and c = 10.669) reveals that, although the b and c axes are similar in dimensions, the a axis of the Mn-FINA-1 unit cell is approximately double that of Cd-FINA-1 (doubling of the a axis is expected from randomization/disorder of the pyridine ring orientations in the Cd-FINA-1 structure), which was previously observed in the case of Co-INA-2 and Co-FINA-2 (Tables S1, S2, S7, and S8). Despite having similar unit cells and crystal structures, Mn-INA-1 has bigger pore dimensions (2.8 × 6.5 Å2) compared to Mn-FINA-1 (2.1 × 3.4 Å2) because the F atoms point into the pores (). Similarly, the interpenetrated structure of Cd-INA-1 (2.2 × 6.6 Å2) has higher pore dimensions than those of Cd-FINA-1 (2.6 × 3.1 Å2).

elements.content: Structures of pyridinecarboxylate-based MOFs. The packing diagrams of MOFs with and without fluorine functionalization are achieved using INA/FINA and PAA/FPAA linkers. H atoms are omitted for clarity. Color codes: Mn, green; Co, brown; Cd, violet; C, silver; F, light green; O, red; N, light blue.
elements.clean_text: 2  Structures of pyridinecarboxylate-based MOFs. The packing diagrams of MOFs with and without fluorine functionalization are achieved using INA/FINA and PAA/FPAA linkers. H atoms are omitted for clarity. Color codes: Mn, green; Co, brown; Cd, violet; C, silver; F, light green; O, red; N, light blue.

elements.content: The crystal structures of MOFs synthesized using PAA and FPAA linkers with Mn, Co, and Cd metals consist of doubly bridged infinite manganese­(2+)/cobalt­(2+)/cadmium­(2+) carboxylate chains in all of the MOFs, where pyridine functionalities of PAA and FPAA ligands point out of the chains ( and S7–S12). The resulting strands cross-link by metal–N coordination to generate 3D frameworks, similar to those observed in the cases of MOFs synthesized using INA and FINA linkers. Except Co-PAA-1 and Cd-PAA-1, all other MOF structures are noninterpenetrated, having pore sizes of 7–8 Å. The crystal structures of Mn-PAA-1 and Mn-FPAA-1 are almost similar, wherein octahedral Mn2+ metal centers are coordinated to four μ2-carboxyl O atoms and two pyridyl N atoms from PAA and FPAA linkers, respectively (Figures S6–S8). In the Mn-PAA-1 crystal structure, it has been observed that two DMF molecules are parallely positioned in the center of each pore having dimensions of 7.6 × 7.7 Å2 (). However, in the case of Mn-FPPA-1, there exist only one DMF molecule in the pore center, despite their similar pore dimensions (7.2 × 7.9 Å2). The crystal structure Cd-FPAA-1 is isostructural to Mn-FPAA-1, with octahedral Cd2+ metal centers and similar pore dimensions of 7.1 × 8.5 Å2 (Figure S10). However, the crystal structure of Co-FPAA-1 consisting of octahedral Co2+ centers is similar to Mn-PAA-1, which has larger pores (7.2 × 9.1 Å2) occupied with two parallelly positioned DMF molecules ( and S12). In contrast, the crystal structure of Cd-PAA-1 has a 2-fold partially interpenetrated structure with trigonal-prismatic Cd2+ centers coordinated to two μ1-carboxyl O atoms and two pyridyl N atoms of PAA linkers (Figure S9). Two independent Cd-PAA linker chains stabilized together by weak hydrogen bonding get intermingled with each other, generating a partially interpenetrated structure. Despite interpenetration, Cd-PAA-1 has large-sized pores (8.7 × 8.2 Å2) occupied by disordered DMF molecules. Similarly, the crystal structure of Co-PAA-1 is highly interpenetrated with trigonal-prismatic Co2+ centers coordinated to two μ1-carboxyl O atoms and two pyridyl N atoms of PAA linkers, which is reported elsewhere in the literature (Figure S11). Because of the high degree of interpenetration, the structure of Co-PAA-1 is nonporous, with trigonal pores comprised of small dimensions (4.5 × 4.2 Å2). We believe that the change in the crystal systems for Mn-PAA-1, Co-PAA-1, and Cd-PAA-1 originates from the different electronic properties of the metal centers used for MOF synthesis. From the crystal structures of PAA- and FPAA-based MOFs, it is clear that, by utilization of rigid fluorinated linkers, noninterpenetrated MOFs can be easily synthesized. The detailed investigation of the crystal structures confirms that, by taking advantage of the longer lengths of the PAA and FPAA linkers than those of the INA and FINA linkers, synthesis of isoreticular Mn-, Co-, and Cd-based MOFs can be successfully achieved (Tables S3–S6, S9, and S10).
elements.clean_text: The crystal structures of MOFs synthesized using PAA and FPAA linkers with Mn, Co, and Cd metals consist of doubly bridged infinite manganese(2+)/cobalt(2+)/cadmium(2+) carboxylate chains in all of the MOFs, where pyridine functionalities of PAA and FPAA ligands point out of the chains ( and S7-S12). The resulting strands cross-link by metal-N coordination to generate 3D frameworks, similar to those observed in the cases of MOFs synthesized using INA and FINA linkers. Except Co-PAA-1 and Cd-PAA-1, all other MOF structures are noninterpenetrated, having pore sizes of 7-8 Å. The crystal structures of Mn-PAA-1 and Mn-FPAA-1 are almost similar, wherein octahedral Mn2+ metal centers are coordinated to four μ2-carboxyl O atoms and two pyridyl N atoms from PAA and FPAA linkers, respectively (Figures S6-S8). In the Mn-PAA-1 crystal structure, it has been observed that two DMF molecules are parallely positioned in the center of each pore having dimensions of 7.6 × 7.7 Å2 (). However, in the case of Mn-FPPA-1, there exist only one DMF molecule in the pore center, despite their similar pore dimensions (7.2 × 7.9 Å2). The crystal structure Cd-FPAA-1 is isostructural to Mn-FPAA-1, with octahedral Cd2+ metal centers and similar pore dimensions of 7.1 × 8.5 Å2 (Figure S10). However, the crystal structure of Co-FPAA-1 consisting of octahedral Co2+ centers is similar to Mn-PAA-1, which has larger pores (7.2 × 9.1 Å2) occupied with two parallelly positioned DMF molecules ( and S12). In contrast, the crystal structure of Cd-PAA-1 has a 2-fold partially interpenetrated structure with trigonal-prismatic Cd2+ centers coordinated to two μ1-carboxyl O atoms and two pyridyl N atoms of PAA linkers (Figure S9). Two independent Cd-PAA linker chains stabilized together by weak hydrogen bonding get intermingled with each other, generating a partially interpenetrated structure. Despite interpenetration, Cd-PAA-1 has large-sized pores (8.7 × 8.2 Å2) occupied by disordered DMF molecules. Similarly, the crystal structure of Co-PAA-1 is highly interpenetrated with trigonal-prismatic Co2+ centers coordinated to two μ1-carboxyl O atoms and two pyridyl N atoms of PAA linkers, which is reported elsewhere in the literature (Figure S11). Because of the high degree of interpenetration, the structure of Co-PAA-1 is nonporous, with trigonal pores comprised of small dimensions (4.5 × 4.2 Å2). We believe that the change in the crystal systems for Mn-PAA-1, Co-PAA-1, and Cd-PAA-1 originates from the different electronic properties of the metal centers used for MOF synthesis. From the crystal structures of PAA- and FPAA-based MOFs, it is clear that, by utilization of rigid fluorinated linkers, noninterpenetrated MOFs can be easily synthesized. The detailed investigation of the crystal structures confirms that, by taking advantage of the longer lengths of the PAA and FPAA linkers than those of the INA and FINA linkers, synthesis of isoreticular Mn-, Co-, and Cd-based MOFs can be successfully achieved (Tables S3-S6, S9, and S10).

elements.content: In order to confirm the phase purity of the bulk MOFs, PXRD experiments were carried out using as-synthesized materials. The experimental PXRD patterns of as-synthesized MOFs with their computer-simulated patterns for all of the MOFs are shown in Figures S13 and S14. As shown in the figures, all major peaks of the experimental PXRD patterns of compounds Mn-INA-1, Mn-FINA-1, Cd-INA-1, Cd-FINA-1, Mn-PAA-1, and Cd-PAA-1 match quite well with those of the simulated PXRD patterns, indicating their reasonable crystalline phase purity. The experimental patterns of Co-PAA-1, Co-FPAA-1, Mn-FPAA-1, and Cd-FPAA-1 have a few diffraction lines that are unindexed and some that are slightly broadened in comparison with the simulated patterns. This is probably due to the loss of DMF molecules from the lattice during the grinding of materials for analysis. IR analysis of MOFs reveals the presence of all of the characteristics peaks for the functionalities present in MOFs (Figures S15–S19). The absence of additional peaks in the PXRD and IR patterns of all of the MOFs, except their characteristic peaks, confirmed the absence of any additional impurities. TGA performed on as-synthesized Mn-PAA-1 and Mn-FPAA-1 revealed that these compounds have high thermal stability beyond 300 °C (Figure S21). The TGA trace for as-synthesized Mn-PAA-1 and Mn-FPAA-1 showed gradual weight-loss steps of 19.6 and 9.3%, respectively, corresponding to the escape of coordinated and free DMF and EtOH molecules from the pores. From these analyses, it is clear that MOFs synthesized from transition metals and pyridinecarboxylate linkers have high thermal stabilities.
elements.clean_text:
PXRD, FTIR, and Thermal Analyses

In order to confirm the phase purity of the bulk MOFs, PXRD experiments were carried out using as-synthesized materials. The experimental PXRD patterns of as-synthesized MOFs with their computer-simulated patterns for all of the MOFs are shown in Figures S13 and S14. As shown in the figures, all major peaks of the experimental PXRD patterns of compounds Mn-INA-1, Mn-FINA-1, Cd-INA-1, Cd-FINA-1, Mn-PAA-1, and Cd-PAA-1 match quite well with those of the simulated PXRD patterns, indicating their reasonable crystalline phase purity. The experimental patterns of Co-PAA-1, Co-FPAA-1, Mn-FPAA-1, and Cd-FPAA-1 have a few diffraction lines that are unindexed and some that are slightly broadened in comparison with the simulated patterns. This is probably due to the loss of DMF molecules from the lattice during the grinding of materials for analysis. IR analysis of MOFs reveals the presence of all of the characteristics peaks for the functionalities present in MOFs (Figures S15-S19). The absence of additional peaks in the PXRD and IR patterns of all of the MOFs, except their characteristic peaks, confirmed the absence of any additional impurities. TGA performed on as-synthesized Mn-PAA-1 and Mn-FPAA-1 revealed that these compounds have high thermal stability beyond 300 °C (Figure S21). The TGA trace for as-synthesized Mn-PAA-1 and Mn-FPAA-1 showed gradual weight-loss steps of 19.6 and 9.3%, respectively, corresponding to the escape of coordinated and free DMF and EtOH molecules from the pores. From these analyses, it is clear that MOFs synthesized from transition metals and pyridinecarboxylate linkers have high thermal stabilities.

elements.content: Analyses of the crystal structures of Mn-, Co-, and Cd-PAA-1 and Mn-, Co-, and Cd-FPAA-1 reveal that these MOFs are porous with moderate solvent-accessible voids, despite the presence of protruding F atoms in the pores of F-MOFs. Except Co-PAA-1, all other MOFs have square-shaped pores, which are occupied by solvent molecules. These results motivated us to study the N2 and H2 adsorption properties of these MOFs. Prior to gas adsorption experiments, guest and coordinated solvent molecules are removed by solvent exchange followed by thermal activation at an optimized temperature using ultrahigh vacuum. The permanent porosities of PAA- and FPAA-based MOFs were confirmed by N2 adsorption isotherms because these MOFs have pore sizes higher than the kinetic diameter of N2 (3.6 Å). Except Co-PAA-1, all other MOFs show reversible type I N2 adsorption isotherms at 77 K (Figure S20). Because of the 3-fold-interpenetrated structure and very small pores (4.6 × 4.3 Å2), Co-PAA-1 shows a very low Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area (24 m2 g–1). However, because of its rigid structure and larger pores, Co-FPAA-1 has a BET surface area of 449 m2 g–1, which is higher than its nonfluorinated isomer (Co-PAA-1). The higher surface area of Mn-PAA-1 (610 m2 g–1) than that of Mn-FPAA-1 (337 m2 g–1) can be attributed to the higher pore dimensions and solvent-accessible voids (Figure S20). As shown in , as a result of higher van der Waals radii of fluorine (1.47 Å) than hydrogen (1.20 Å), lower pore dimensions have been observed in Mn-FPAA-1 than in Mn-PAA-1, despite their similar structures. Similarly, Cd-PAA-1 has a higher surface area than Cd-FPAA-1 because the former has larger pores with higher solvent-accessible voids (). In all of FPAA-based MOFs, despite their comparable pore dimensions with PAA-based MOFs, the lower surface area suggests the incomplete removal of guest solvent molecules (DMF) from the MOF pores because of strong hydrogen-bonding interactions between F atoms from linkers and solvent molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Adsorption

Analyses of the crystal structures of Mn-, Co-, and Cd-PAA-1 and Mn-, Co-, and Cd-FPAA-1 reveal that these MOFs are porous with moderate solvent-accessible voids, despite the presence of protruding F atoms in the pores of F-MOFs. Except Co-PAA-1, all other MOFs have square-shaped pores, which are occupied by solvent molecules. These results motivated us to study the N2 and H2 adsorption properties of these MOFs. Prior to gas adsorption experiments, guest and coordinated solvent molecules are removed by solvent exchange followed by thermal activation at an optimized temperature using ultrahigh vacuum. The permanent porosities of PAA- and FPAA-based MOFs were confirmed by N2 adsorption isotherms because these MOFs have pore sizes higher than the kinetic diameter of N2 (3.6 Å). Except Co-PAA-1, all other MOFs show reversible type I N2 adsorption isotherms at 77 K (Figure S20). Because of the 3-fold-interpenetrated structure and very small pores (4.6 × 4.3 Å2), Co-PAA-1 shows a very low Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area (24 m2 g-1). However, because of its rigid structure and larger pores, Co-FPAA-1 has a BET surface area of 449 m2 g-1, which is higher than its nonfluorinated isomer (Co-PAA-1). The higher surface area of Mn-PAA-1 (610 m2 g-1) than that of Mn-FPAA-1 (337 m2 g-1) can be attributed to the higher pore dimensions and solvent-accessible voids (Figure S20). As shown in , as a result of higher van der Waals radii of fluorine (1.47 Å) than hydrogen (1.20 Å), lower pore dimensions have been observed in Mn-FPAA-1 than in Mn-PAA-1, despite their similar structures. Similarly, Cd-PAA-1 has a higher surface area than Cd-FPAA-1 because the former has larger pores with higher solvent-accessible voids (). In all of FPAA-based MOFs, despite their comparable pore dimensions with PAA-based MOFs, the lower surface area suggests the incomplete removal of guest solvent molecules (DMF) from the MOF pores because of strong hydrogen-bonding interactions between F atoms from linkers and solvent molecules.

elements.content:
Summary of the Structural Information of MOFs with Their Porosity Details MOF cryst syst space group surface area (m2 g–1) H2 uptake (wt %) Mn-INA-1 monoclinic P21 Mn-FINA-1 monoclinic P21 Mn-PAA-1 monoclinic P21/c 610 1.09 Mn-FPAA-1 monoclinic P21/c 337 0.97 Co-INA-2 monoclinic P21 93 0.52 Co-FINA-2 monoclinic P21/c 153 0.82 Co-PAA-1 monoclinic Cc 24 0.54 Co-FPAA-1 monoclinic P21/c 449 1.16 Cd-INA-1 orthorhombic Pbca Cd-FINA-1 monoclinic P21/c Cd-PAA-1 orthorhombic Pnna 795 1.30 Cd-FPAA-1 monoclinic P21/c 298 1.20

Reported in the literature.

Further, because we confirmed the permanent porosity of all of the PAA- and FPAA-based MOFs from N2 adsorption isotherm, we have collected the H2 adsorption isotherms (). All of these MOFs show reversible type I isotherms at 77 K and 1 atm, suggesting the reversible adsorption of H2 (). Among these MOFs reported herein, isostructural Cd-PAA-1 (1.30 wt %) and Cd-FPAA-1 (1.20 wt %) show the highest H2 uptakes in this series (c), while isostructural Mn-PAA-1 and Mn-FPAA-1 adsorb 1.09 and 0.97 wt % of H2, as shown in a. Co-FPAA adsorbs an H2 amount almost similar to that of Cd-FPAA-1, showing 1.16 wt % uptake at analogous conditions, as the pressure approaches 1 atm (b). As expected, because of very small pores and low solvent-accessible voids, Co-PAA-1 shows less than 0.54 wt % hydrogen uptake. Although Co-PAA-1 shows nonporous structure, as determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and N2 adsorption isotherms, it shows moderate hydrogen uptake due to the low kinetic diameter of H2 (2.89 Å) and the suitability of pores present in Co-PAA-1 for H2 adsorption. Additionally, the steep rise of the H2 uptake capacities at low pressure (>0.2 atm) in all of the MOFs reported herein suggests the utility of these MOFs for hydrogen storage. From the H2 adsorption properties of PAA- and FPAA-based MOFs, it is clear that structures of FPAA-based MOFs are porous and noninterpenetrated, which shows a consistent gas adsorption uptake performance, probably because of the rigid structures of FPAA linkers present in MOF backbones. On the contrary, the structures of PAA-based MOFs are partially or highly interpenetrated (except Mn-PAA-1) without any consistencies in porosities as well as gas uptake properties, suggesting the importance of functionalization for avoiding interpenetration as well as improving the gas uptake properties.
elements.clean_text: Further, because we confirmed the permanent porosity of all of the PAA- and FPAA-based MOFs from N2 adsorption isotherm, we have collected the H2 adsorption isotherms (). All of these MOFs show reversible type I isotherms at 77 K and 1 atm, suggesting the reversible adsorption of H2 (). Among these MOFs reported herein, isostructural Cd-PAA-1 (1.30 wt %) and Cd-FPAA-1 (1.20 wt %) show the highest H2 uptakes in this series (c), while isostructural Mn-PAA-1 and Mn-FPAA-1 adsorb 1.09 and 0.97 wt % of H2, as shown in a. Co-FPAA adsorbs an H2 amount almost similar to that of Cd-FPAA-1, showing 1.16 wt % uptake at analogous conditions, as the pressure approaches 1 atm (b). As expected, because of very small pores and low solvent-accessible voids, Co-PAA-1 shows less than 0.54 wt % hydrogen uptake. Although Co-PAA-1 shows nonporous structure, as determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and N2 adsorption isotherms, it shows moderate hydrogen uptake due to the low kinetic diameter of H2 (2.89 Å) and the suitability of pores present in Co-PAA-1 for H2 adsorption. Additionally, the steep rise of the H2 uptake capacities at low pressure (>0.2 atm) in all of the MOFs reported herein suggests the utility of these MOFs for hydrogen storage. From the H2 adsorption properties of PAA- and FPAA-based MOFs, it is clear that structures of FPAA-based MOFs are porous and noninterpenetrated, which shows a consistent gas adsorption uptake performance, probably because of the rigid structures of FPAA linkers present in MOF backbones. On the contrary, the structures of PAA-based MOFs are partially or highly interpenetrated (except Mn-PAA-1) without any consistencies in porosities as well as gas uptake properties, suggesting the importance of functionalization for avoiding interpenetration as well as improving the gas uptake properties.

elements.content: H2 adsorption isotherms of Mn-PAA-1 and Mn-FPAA-1 (a), Co-PAA-1 and Co-FPAA-1 (b), and Cd-PAA-1 and Cd-FPAA-1 (c). Closed and open circles represent adsorption and desorption branches, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 3  H2 adsorption isotherms of Mn-PAA-1 and Mn-FPAA-1 (a), Co-PAA-1 and Co-FPAA-1 (b), and Cd-PAA-1 and Cd-FPAA-1 (c). Closed and open circles represent adsorption and desorption branches, respectively.

elements.content: The moderate H2 uptakes shown by the fluorinated Cd-FPAA-1 and Co-FPAA-1, at low pressure (1 bar), are comparable to those of F-MOFs such as [Ag2(Ag4-Tz6)], [Zn5(triazole)6(tfbdc)2(H2O)2]·4H2O, TKL-104, Co-FINA-1, F-MOF-4, F-MOF-6, and Cu-TBA-2F, which have H2 uptakes ranging between 0.45 and 2.0 wt %, respectively. Further, the H2 uptakes shown by Cd-FPAA-1 and Co-FPAA-1 at 77 K and 1 atm pressure are comparable to those of MOFs like Mg/DOBDC and Zn2(BDC)2(DABCO) and outperform those of well-known MOFs like Co/DOBDC, Zn/DOBDC, CUK-1, Bio-MOF-11, MOF-177, and MOF-5 and ZIFs like ZIF-11 and ZIF-8 reported in the literature. On the other hand, higher H2 uptake capacities of Co-PAA-1 and Co-FPAA-1 compared to those of Co-INA-2 and Co-FINA-2 confirm the importance of isoreticulation for elevated H2 uptake in MOFs (). The simultaneous effect of isoreticulation and functionalization in Co-PAA-1 and Co-FPAA-1 has been clearly visualized for elevated H2 uptake. From the H2 uptake shown by F-MOFs, it is clear that the H2 uptake in F-MOFs is not a universal phenomenon but is system-specific, and other factors such as pore sizes, curvatures, open metal sites, etc., also can play crucial roles in high gas uptakes.
elements.clean_text: The moderate H2 uptakes shown by the fluorinated Cd-FPAA-1 and Co-FPAA-1, at low pressure (1 bar), are comparable to those of F-MOFs such as [Ag2(Ag4-Tz6)], [Zn5(triazole)6(tfbdc)2(H2O)2]⋅4H2O, TKL-104, Co-FINA-1, F-MOF-4, F-MOF-6, and Cu-TBA-2F, which have H2 uptakes ranging between 0.45 and 2.0 wt %, respectively. Further, the H2 uptakes shown by Cd-FPAA-1 and Co-FPAA-1 at 77 K and 1 atm pressure are comparable to those of MOFs like Mg/DOBDC and Zn2(BDC)2(DABCO) and outperform those of well-known MOFs like Co/DOBDC, Zn/DOBDC, CUK-1, Bio-MOF-11, MOF-177, and MOF-5 and ZIFs like ZIF-11 and ZIF-8 reported in the literature. On the other hand, higher H2 uptake capacities of Co-PAA-1 and Co-FPAA-1 compared to those of Co-INA-2 and Co-FINA-2 confirm the importance of isoreticulation for elevated H2 uptake in MOFs (). The simultaneous effect of isoreticulation and functionalization in Co-PAA-1 and Co-FPAA-1 has been clearly visualized for elevated H2 uptake. From the H2 uptake shown by F-MOFs, it is clear that the H2 uptake in F-MOFs is not a universal phenomenon but is system-specific, and other factors such as pore sizes, curvatures, open metal sites, etc., also can play crucial roles in high gas uptakes.

elements.content: In summary, we have synthesized F-MOFs using FINA and FPAA linkers with Mn2+, Co2+, and Cd2+ metal centers via the solvothermal method, which show isostructural isomerism with its nonfluorinated counterparts synthesized using INA and PAA. Herein, we could achieve isostructural isomerism in fluorinated and nonfluorinated MOFs using partially fluorinated and nonfluorinated linkers. The simultaneous effect of isoreticulation and functionalization in MOFs has been clearly visualized for elevated hydrogen uptake using pairs of isoreticular and functionalized MOFs. A comparison of the H2 uptake properties of isostructural fluorinated and nonfluorinated MOFs shows that high H2 uptake in the fluorinated counterparts is not a universal phenomenon but is rather system-specific and differs from system to system.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have synthesized F-MOFs using FINA and FPAA linkers with Mn2+, Co2+, and Cd2+ metal centers via the solvothermal method, which show isostructural isomerism with its nonfluorinated counterparts synthesized using INA and PAA. Herein, we could achieve isostructural isomerism in fluorinated and nonfluorinated MOFs using partially fluorinated and nonfluorinated linkers. The simultaneous effect of isoreticulation and functionalization in MOFs has been clearly visualized for elevated hydrogen uptake using pairs of isoreticular and functionalized MOFs. A comparison of the H2 uptake properties of isostructural fluorinated and nonfluorinated MOFs shows that high H2 uptake in the fluorinated counterparts is not a universal phenomenon but is rather system-specific and differs from system to system.

PXRD, FTIR, and Thermal Analyses

In order to confirm the phase purity of the bulk MOFs, PXRD experiments were carried out using as-synthesized materials. The experimental PXRD patterns of as-synthesized MOFs with their computer-simulated patterns for all of the MOFs are shown in Figures S13 and S14. As shown in the figures, all major peaks of the experimental PXRD patterns of compounds Mn-INA-1, Mn-FINA-1, Cd-INA-1, Cd-FINA-1, Mn-PAA-1, and Cd-PAA-1 match quite well with those of the simulated PXRD patterns, indicating their reasonable crystalline phase purity. The experimental patterns of Co-PAA-1, Co-FPAA-1, Mn-FPAA-1, and Cd-FPAA-1 have a few diffraction lines that are unindexed and some that are slightly broadened in comparison with the simulated patterns. This is probably due to the loss of DMF molecules from the lattice during the grinding of materials for analysis. The absence of additional peaks in the PXRD and IR patterns of all of the MOFs, except their characteristic peaks, confirmed the absence of any additional impurities. cln_elements.content: Synthesis and crystal structures of MOFs. Scheme of the synthesis of MOFs using INA, FINA, PAA, and FPAA linkers with Mn2+, Co2+, and Cd2+ metal centers, solvothermally. The SBUs of the nonfluorinated MOFs and their partially fluorinated isomers are represented. H atoms are omitted for clarity. Color code: Mn, green; Co, brown; Cd, violet; C, silver; F, light green; O, red; N, light blue.

metadata.title:
Functionalization and Isoreticulation in a Series
of Metal–Organic Frameworks Derived from Pyridinecarboxylates
